bibl.title: John Matthews v. Henry M. White. Warrant

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: WARRANT-ARREST OF ALIEN United States of America WASHINGTON
To HENRY M. WHITE, Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Wash., Or to any Immigration Inspector in the service of the United States

WHEREAS, from evidence submitted to me, it appears that the alien
JOHN MATTHEWS,
who landed at an unknown port,
on or about the 1st day of Sept., 1919, has been found in the United States in violation of the immigration act of February 5, 1917, for the following among other reasons:
That he has been sentenced, subsequent to the passage of said Act, to imprisonment for a term of one year or more because of conviction in this country of a crime involving moral turpitude committed within five years after his entry into the United States; and that he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry.

I LOUIS F. POST, Assistant Secretary of Labor, by virtue of the power and authority vested in me by the laws of the United States, do hereby command you to take into custody the said alien and grant him a hearing - - - - - to enable him to show cause why he should not be deported in conformity with law.

The expenses of detention hereunder, if necessary, are authorized, payable from the appropriation: "Expenses of Regulating Immigration, 1921" Pending further proceedings the alien may be released from custody upon furnishing satisfactory bond in the sum of $1000.
For doing so, this shall be your sufficient warrant. Witness my hand and seal this 5th day of November, 1920
LOUIS F. POST Assistant Secretary of Labor.
APPLICATION FOR WARRANT OF ARREST UNDER SECTION 19 OF THE ACT OF FEBRUARY 5, 1917
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF LABOR IMMIGRATION SERVICE
(Place) Seattle, Washington November 4, 1920

The undersigned respectfully recommends that the Secretary of Labor issue his warrant for the arrest of JOHN MATTHEWS the alien named in the attached certificate, upon the following facts which the undersigned has carefully investigated, and which, to the best of his knowledge and belief are true:

(1) Here state fully facts which show alien to be unlawfully in the United States. Give sources of information, and where possible, secure from informants and forward with this application duly verified affidavits setting forth the facts within the knowledge of the informants.)

1. Alien was, at the time of his entry to the United States through the port of Vancouver, B.C., September, 1919, a person likely to become a public charge. 2. He has been sentenced to serve a ter, of more than one year because of conviction in this country of a crime involving moral turpitude within five years after his entry to the United States.

Alien is 29 years of age, a native of Austria, and lived in different parts of Canada from the time he was 15 years old until the time of his entry to the United States through the port of Vancouver, B.C., September, 1919. Alien has never taken steps to become a citizen of Canada. Un November, 1919, alien was arrested in Alaska and charged with sending obscene matter through the mail, and was tried at Valdez, Alaska. On May 4, 1920, he was sentenced to serve a term of one year and a day at the McNeil Island Penitentiary.
(2) The present location and occupation of above, named alien are as follows: United States Penitentiary, McNeil Island, Washington.

Pursuant to Rule 22 of the Immigration Regulations there is attached hereto and made a part hereof the certificate prescribed in subdivision 2 of said Rule, as to the landing or entry of said alien, duly signed by the immigration officer in charge at the port through which said alien entered the United States.
(Signature) Hentry M. White (Official title) Commissioner.
FILED IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COUNTY Western District of Washington NORTHERN DIVISION
SEP 12 1921 F.M. HARSHBERGER, CLERK By S.E. Lietch Deputy.
